title: Egyptian Tombs: Designing for the Afterlife
description: A quick, practical guide to Egyptian Tombs: Designing for the Afterlife.

hook.text: Ancient Egyptians spent more time designing tombs than homes. The afterlife was the real living room.

buildup.text: Tomb interiors included painted walls, gilded furniture, and even board games for eternity.

discovery.text: King Tut's tomb had a golden throne, alabaster lamps, and a bed â€” a fully furnished apartment for the dead.

twist.text: Living Egyptians slept on simple mats. Their best design work went underground.

climax.text: Egyptian tomb design tells us that interiors reflect values â€” and their highest value was immortality.

punchline.text: The first interior designers worked for clients who were already dead.

quiz.question: Why were Egyptian tombs more elaborately designed than homes?
options: The afterlife was considered more important
